Award.AwardTitle: Embodied STEM Learning Across Technology- Based Learning Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project conducts interdisciplinary research to advance understanding of embodied learning as it applies to STEM topics across a range of current technology-based learning environments (e.g., desktop simulations, interactive whiteboards, and 3D interactive environments). The project builds on extensive research, including prior work of the PIs, regarding both embodied learning and statistical learning. The PIs describe embodied learning as engaging the neuromuscular systems of learners as they interact with the world around them visually, aurally, and kinesthetically in order to construct new knowledge structures. Statistical learning is described as the ability to learn, often without intent, which sequences of stimuli are consistent with a set of rules. An example of statistical learning is pattern recognition, which is central to mastery of complex topics in many STEM disciplines including physics and mathematics.

The project has two central research questions: How are student knowledge gains impacted by the degree of embodied learning and to what extent do the affordances of different technology-based learning environments constrain or support embodied learning for STEM topics? To investigate these questions, the PIs are conducting three series of experiments in five phases using two physics topics. The first four phases are developmental and the final phase implements and assesses the two modules in schools (20 plus teachers, 700 plus K-12 students) in Arizona and New York (15 total sites, 10 plus public schools, minimum one Title I school).

The aim of this project is to meld these two research trajectories to yield two key outcomes: 1) basic research regarding embodiment and statistical learning that can be applied to create powerful STEM learning experiences, and 2) the realization of exemplary models and principles to aid curriculum and technology designers in creating learning scenarios that take into account the level of embodiment that a given learning environment affords.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes             PI: Johnson-Glenberg

Intellectual Merit  

New platforms are emerging for science education. Designers and instructors need to know how effective these platforms are for learning and if embodiment that is afforded by the platforms also affects learning. The data produced by this grant demonstrate that greater gains in learning are found when learners are in more embodied environments. For the first study that focused on Centripetal Force, the two take away points were 1) that the amount of embodiment was more important than the platform, and 2) that the effects of learning via embodiment did not show up on immediate posttests. An effect for embodiment as a significant predictor of knowledge retention was seen on the more generative subtest given one week post-intervention. In addition, we created a taxonomy on embodiment to help designers as they create educational content. The term embodiment can sometimes be unclear and we proposed four defined degrees that describe the "amount of embodiment" in a lesson.

The second large study tackled the abstract concept of the Electric Field. The control condition was created with Symbols and Text only and the experimental conditions varied the amount of activity (controlling icons on screen via gesture). The final, or fourth condition, contained a gamelike narrative to string together the various mini-lessons.

The outcomes in learning gains were:

Symbols+Text control < passive and embodied < active and embodied = active and narrative

The two last conditions performed similarly. We interpret this to mean that allowing participants to use large gestures and create vectors in 3D space that manipulated the models on the screen led to greater learning gains, compared to passively observing the models being made.

A major outcome of this study was that a new assessment measure was created that was more sensitive to learning via gesture. Two types of tests were used in the study: 1) a traditional text-based physics test answered with a keyboard; 2) an innovative, more embodied-transfer test using the Intuous Wacom large tablet. With the large tablet learners could use larger swiping hand gestures to create vectors and answers. When knowledge was assessed via the larger tablet format that facilitated gestures, the two active high embodied groups that learned with the Kinect sensor scored significantly higher than the other two groups. The predicted differences in engagement and learning for the condition with the graphically-rich story narrative were not supported. It may be the case that one hour, one-setting experimental sessions do not need narrative storylines to further increase engagement and learning and that the narrative effect on motivation is difficult to uncover in a lab experiment where participants are primarily motivated to finish by receiving assured course credit.

Broader Impacts

By working with multiple middle and high school teachers on the creation of games we have served as ambassadors making educators more cognizant of the role of new multimedia in learning and embodied methods of instruction. We will continue to create innovative embodied content on smaller form devices and encourage more embodied forms of testing (like using the Wacom tablet).

Many of the eight learning objects and games created with this grant are available on the website www.embodied-games.com for teachers and students to use free of charge.

The grant had broad positive impacts on multiple populations including undergraduate and graduate students, STEM teachers, the programmers, and graphic artists who worked on the project. In addition, in 2014 the PI started a spinout company from Arizona State University called Embodied Games, LLC.  This will be a sustainable small company dedicated to building science education games for middle and high school students.
